head.title: Broadwater's Plan For Long Island Sound

hedline.hl1: Broadwater's Plan For Long Island Sound

abstract.p: Long Island Sound Study Citizens Advisory Committee member Warren Ross opposes Broadwater's plan to build liquefied natural gas plant in Sound

block.p: Re the encouraging renewal of Long Island Sound (''Renewal in the Sound,'' editorial, April 22), two points, one hopeful, the other scary, need to be added. The first is to give due credit for the progress you cite to the Long Island Sound Study, the partnership that has been implementing the 1998 cleanup agreement you refer to. The other can be summed up in a word: Broadwater.

Re the encouraging renewal of Long Island Sound (''Renewal in the Sound,'' editorial, April 22), two points, one hopeful, the other scary, need to be added. The first is to give due credit for the progress you cite to the Long Island Sound Study, the partnership that has been implementing the 1998 cleanup agreement you refer to. The other can be summed up in a word: Broadwater.

Broadwater is the liquefied natural gas plant planned for the west end of the sound. It will be 1,200 feet long and 80 feet high, surrounded by a security zone of close to seven-tenths of a mile. The plant will be brought in by ocean-going tankers and transmitted to the mainland by a new underwater pipeline.

As a member of the Long Island Sound Study Citizens Advisory Committee (representing Federated Conservationists of Westchester), I have listened to eloquent debates as to just how much environmental damage this industrial facility might do. But one thing is certain: the sound will never be the same.
